34831751.review: 这个游戏是一款健身类的VR游戏，健身减肥必备。进入游戏界面的时候,会有一种错觉,好像进入到了一款枪击游戏和反恐游戏。整个背景色是非常浓郁的黑色,难以程度选择项则是非常显眼跳跃的荧光亮色系。我第一次置身其中时,感觉身处的环境很诡异，整个游戏里的环境看起来有点复古的味道,像很早的电子风格,音乐搭配的也恰到到处,有节奏点,会让你有运动起来的欲望。初次体验,选择最简单的EASY模式。第一次玩的时候,会有两种感觉,明明感觉自己接住了球,为什么显示没接住。对手玩家为什么那么厉害,常常以5:0的大优势分分钟结束游戏。开始游戏后,会进入到一个封闭的环境中,头顶上就是记录分数的显示牌。之后在你的前方会出现一个球,你手上拿的Vive手柄也会变成一个球拍,这个时候你就可以用你的球拍去打你的球,当球撞击到墙面或地面的时候会进行反弹,反弹多次,这个球就已经输掉啦。这款游戏就是将你的球打入对方的门里,并且要接住对手打给你的球,对手就是对面墙上的红方块,当你打出一些快速度的球或者一些高难度的球时,它就会产生纰漏,而你将获得一分。游戏的赛点是五,如果你先拿到五分,就可以进入到下一局。游戏的玩法十分简单,没什么特别的要求,也不需要什么特殊的技能,每晋级一关,球的速度会加快,游戏会越来越激烈,难度也会增加。所以,这款游戏看似容易,其实也在考验着你的运动细胞。在玩这款游戏的时候所处的房间一定不要有障碍物!一定不要有障碍物!一定不要有障碍物!重要的事情说三遍。手柄撞到飞出去事小,自己磕到撞到事大。一定要说的就是这款游戏真的非常耗费体力,与真实生活中打羽毛球、网球等运动无异。当你发现越用力的击球,球越容易“破门而入”取得胜利,就会情不自禁的用尽全身力气来打球。我是用大朋E3定位版VR头盔玩的，常常打完几局后就已经满头大汗,筋疲力尽。所以特别锻炼身体。

30180870.review:
This game is so close to being perfect.  For the first hour, I was in love with this game.  It was after the first hour that the issues began to arise.  The first is that the AI shoots the ball right on the edge of the play space.  Now, they do have a way to add padding to your play space to keep you from hitting walls, and that's a great thing to have, but when the AI is consistently throwing shots that make you fearful of hitting a wall (I hit a picture frame and smashed the glass) it stops being fun.  Tweaking the AI to keep it from throwing so many shots on the play space line would go a long way.

The other issue is the physics of the ball.  They're just not right.  Hit the ball to the left, and it curves to the right.  It does all these weird curves that make absolutely no sense and make it difficult to have any sort of strategy.  Why try to hit the ball in one direction when it's just going to fly off in the direction it wants to anyway?  That might have to do with the way the paddles are angled in relation to the controllers.  You can't hold the controllers normally and have the paddles be at a normal angle.  It's odd.  Allowing the user to modify the angle of the paddles would be nice.

Overall, fun game.  But if you have a small play area or are looking for a paddle ball game where you can actually control the direction of the ball, look elsewhere.  Though I'm recommending it, I do so with reservations.

Yeah, I had to change my rating after continuing the play.  I just can't recommend this game. The AI is atrocious and the physics governing the ball cause one hit straight on to curve off to the side or even go behind you, which makes this game just too frustrating to bother with.

29317402.review:
This game is extremely fun, challenging and gets you moving. Many people compare it to CyberPong and, having played its demo, I can honestly say that this game is better. 
The main problem with CyberPong, compared to this, is that here the ball actually responds to how quickly you hit it. In CyberPong, the ball goes at the same speed most of the time. In multiplayer, it just speeds up over the course of the point, but gently tapping it has the same result as hitting it with force. Here, you can feel the momentum of your bat/racket/thing getting transferred to the ball. The ball even curves if you hit it right. There is also a subtle vibration as you move your controller, making it feel as though you are actually holding a lightsaber! The music is fantastic and fits very well into the theme of the game, and the visuals make you feel as though you stepped into Tron: Legacy. This is further augmented by what the AI (your opponent) says: things like "next human please" if you lose and "this may be a quirk of the reality we graced you with" if you score a point. Kinda reminds me of GLaDOS, honestly.
To conclude, this game is super fun to play (it kinda feels like a workout after longer sessions) and its atmosphere is spot on. I can't wait for things like multiplayer to be added (which IS listed in the [b]Coming Soon[/b] section in the description, which is nice).

If this review sounded like an essay, I'm sorry, it's the middle of Exam Week.

25310312.review:
If you were born in the 80s, this app will speak to you in a way younger generations can only interpret from their poor cliches and rudimentary tropes.

Mechanically the game play is very straightforward. Your goal is to get the HoloBall to the opposing side of the wireframe, tetrahedron court, whilst preventing your opponent from achieving the same.

Stylistically the design is spot on. A very clean and pure 80's digital distopia, which will remind many of you of the iconic "Tron" films.

The music sets the tone perfectly and compliments the aesthetic too a tee.

Occasionally it feels as if the collider for the paddle is not keeping up with the update cycle. This could be a problem with the Physics Engines update period, (I'd be interested to know if they've got it set at 90FPS). Alternatively I could be getting old and decrepit.

The HoloBall will occasionally ignore that my paddle is inside it's spawn box, which frequently results in own goals whilst I gloat over my perfect serve. This is irritating and unless a real cock up has occured during development, should be a very simple fix.

The obvious feature request would be multiplayer, pvp and co-op would be great fun.

Alternatively someone else will probably create a knock off on this idea and implement the above...

Who knows, my weekend is pretty clear!

All in all, great game, lots of fun, decent work out. Win Win.

24590159.review:
Quick First Impression review since I started this up after midnight and I don't want to disturb any neighbors.

I started the thing up and the first thing that stuck out to me is: WTF is that robot dude saying?  His voice is the worst thing ever.  Imagine some guy making his voice sound unnaturally deep and then standing behind an electric fan and talking and you'll be on the right track.  If you're going to make a robot voice make it intelligible.  Or just make R2D2 sounds and give me subtitles... 

So anyway, the 2nd thing that struck me was "Wow, this is a big fucking room!" and it was... like far bigger than the room I was playing it in... I started to worry that I was going to run into walls.  I tried not to run...This is a game where you will want to run though.  Keep that in mind.

So those things aside, what is this game?  Think "VR pong".  It's like all my old 70's and 80's arcade buddies came back in VR form!  So  yeah, you get a big ole paddle  (One in each hand actually) and a multifaceted VR Ball appears in front of you... swing your paddle and the ball flies towards the big red square that represents your robot AI enemy.  He makes sure his large red square hits the ball and it flies back toward you.   You will likely wind up having to dash a bit to get to the ball in time and thus you start to annoy anyone downstairs. 

At first the only two modes available to you are Zen (where you're just whacking the ball against the wall) and Easy... and I assume to unlock the harder modes you have to beat the easier modes.  Fair enough.  I wouldn't want to challenge the game on hard without proving I'm not going to have a heart attack on medium first anyway.

There isn't a whole lot else to this game (or so it seems).  There was a customize option but I have no idea what options are available to customize.  Maybe paddle size? ball size?  Some kind of documentation would be nice...maybe there is some and I just didn't see it.  It's certainly not in-game though.

Anyway... VR Pong, guys... this is pretty much what you can expect.  It feels a lot like you're playing squash or tennis (minus the net).  I think they could do better with this game if they added some stuff to it though... Maybe change the gravity or add some better sound effects... As it is now, it'll be a good workout (so many games this applies to) but whether that translates to fun or not has yet to be seen.

I'll update this review when I've had more time with it.  For now it gets a tentative thumbs up because it seems to have potential.

24266138.review:
Holoball is the answer to the question "What would Pong look like in the movie Tron?"

If you like racquetball, the classic game Pong and the film Tron, you're going to absolutely love this game. Seriously. You're on a neon light, wire-framed racquetball-type court, with each Vive controller represented as a paddle. Your goal is to hit the holoball past the black/red trash-talking AI square at the far end of the court.

If you own a Vive and want a decent workout, then buy this game. It's quite easy to work up a sweat through this game (you may want to invest in some VR Covers to avoid your headset foam eventually smelling like your gym locker). It's also great fun in addition to the exercise factor.

If you for some reason let go of your controllers at random, do NOT buy this game. Although I've not once came close to letting my Vive controller fly out of my hand, for some reason this game seems to be THE reason for the majority of broken Vive controllers.

And assuming you have replaced the standard Vive wrist-straps with Wii straps ([b]seriously, if not, go order some now because the standard straps WILL FAIL EASILY[/b]), this is a great demo game since it is so easy to pick up and play. Gameplay is literally swinging your arms to hit the ball. No buttons to worry about. No control schemes. Just tell them to use the paddle to hit the ball and let them enjoy the game.

This is one of the most enjoyable games I've played on the Vive. The neon enviroments are vibrant without being too bright or overbearing; combined with it's killer sound track this game immediately drew me in.  I think they nailed the atmoshere, everything from the menus to your first interaction with your opponent are smooth and thematic. No stupid tutorial or long cutscenes you'll be right into this game in seconds.

 You really have to move around your play space during matches, the AI loves hitting into the corners! I really enjoy how hitting the ball feels, your moves really affect how the ball spins/travels and once you get the hang of it smashing aces into that smug robot square is immensely satisfying. This is one game you definitly have to wear the wrist straps and be aware of your enviroment! Even keeping this in mind I managed to send things flying off my desk in the first match when I reached for a hit; be careful! It's not the games fault, it clearly shows you the boundaries. It's just very easy to become immersed in a match and want to pull off a dive or jump shot forgetting you're actually a few ft away from your wall.

For this price you can't go wrong, if you have a vive with some room space you should get this game.

23811714.review:
Seriously, this game is one of the few on Vive I'd be willing to write a review for. First of all, the gameplay is perfection. This game feels like you're really there, playing racketball in the matrix for your life... or something. The rackets, the way they interact and the haptic feedback is superb. Fortunately, because with this type of game it would otherwise be frustrating if the physics and racket+ball interaction didn't feel right. I love serving the ball after each point, it's very rewarding.

Now, on to the graphics and the atmosphere: Simply amazing. The 80's/drive color scheme and "plot" is felt the entire time you play. The AI "enemy" will even stop the music occasionally to talk smack to you or just add to the immersion. Reviews basically saying this is pong are made by people that probably don't appreciate art or anything beyond 1's and 0's, don't listen to them.

Lastly, multiplayer is in the works - per devs.

This game is worth every penny. Of all the "simple-arcadey, demo-like experiences" on the vive, this game actually shines as a worthy "simple" game as it has character beyond. Very few games on the vive feel like actual-games(well-planned and articulated, not just "lets make a VR game and see if it sells").

23556455.review:
VRスポーツゲーム。
Viveのルームスケールを活かして、部屋全体を自分のコートとして使った、コンピューター相手の電子テニスを行う。

Viveコントローラをラケットとし、球を打ち返すだけというシンプルなものだが、ラケットの微細な操作で狙った場所に球を返したり、スピンをかけたカーブボールを打てたりシンプルながらに奥が深く楽しい。
何より打っている感触がとても気持ちよく、狙った場所にボールが上手く入り点数に繋がった時の快感は、全身運動だからなのか非常に高い。
全身を動かして遊ぶことの楽しさを思い出させてくれる一品。
プレイしていると汗だくになるくらいには運動量が多いので運動不足の人にもお勧めしたい。

スポーツ苦手という人でも、EASY～HARDまでは慣れればクリア可能だと思う。自分もスポーツ苦手だけどHARDまではクリアできたので。
また同難易度はリムというゴール端っこのCPUが球を打ち返せないエリアがあるので、そこを狙えば点数を稼げる。
エキスパートからは本当に難しく、リムエリアも除かれ、まさにスポーツのようになってくる。競技用の靴が欲しくなるだろう。

気になったこと
・最低2x2メートルくらいのスペースが必要
・Viveコントローラの標準ストラップは意外と貧弱(手汗でViveコントローラ滑らせた時にストラップの根本がすっぽぬけた。Viveコントローラ自体は頑丈。)

23501389.review:
Of all the early VR experiences out there, I keep coming back to this one. I'm not particularly masterful at any sport (real or otherwise), but this feels well-balanced. I am currently just about beating the computer on Medium every time and now am ready to try Hard. I've found myself gloating at the AI player after a nailing particularly good serve or offhand smash (which includes pointing my right-hand paddle at it and saying "HA F**K YOU LOSER!") and the feeling of personal shame when you fluff a particularly simple shot still gets me. 

Some quick tips:
 - Be mindful of where BOTH paddles are. A couple of times I've tried a backhand and my off-hand has gotten in the way and rebounded the ball back through my own goal.
 - You can tee up the ball on the serve before smashing it. Makes nailing Aces much more likely (my best is 4 in a row). I can foresee that, with practice, I could start to Roddick the crap out of this and hit them every time).
 - Low returns are a bitch. Be prepared to get down low and deflect them back defensively.
 - Don't be afraid of your weaker hand - you might actually find that your % success rate is better as you'll hit so many more across to the other side of the goal and the AI might not make it in time.

I'm looking forward to seeing where this games goes. Oh and the setting just works. Get ready for a Blood-Dragon-Pong-Tron-Athon.

10/10 would swear at my dining room wall again.

I'm a casual racquet ball/tennis player, and after the update this game is now better than ever.

Before the update, this was a great game.  The core game was solid, but my only gripe was that each shot felt more like a ricochet rather than an actual swing. When I would serve the ball with all my might, sometimes it'd be a cannon, and sometimes it'd be a dud. You'd get a lucky defensive shot ricochet with power into the AI's sweet spot. You really just had to make contact to stay competitive with expert AI.

Since the update, ALL these problems have been resolved.  EVERY Time I serve, it zooms across the court like I intended.  Also, those fast serves get a FAST return volley.  If you serve with power, be prepared to react within a split second. Now my defensive shots are slow and easy for the AI to pick up. Against harder AI, you truly have to earn each point and smash the ball into their sweet spot.

It also now gives you a warning to use your wrist straps and perhaps replace your Vive straps with Wii straps. I am a victim of Vive straps breaking off, causing the controller to fly into the wall.  You do not want a $110 repair bill from HTC support. Trust me.

Great game: A must buy for racquet ball, tennis, squash players, or anyone with a mild interest in racquet sports really.

Holoball is a very simple and satisfying VR experience. Anyone who has ever played tennis or raquetball will be able to pick this up without any explanation. The environment is colorful, immersive, and extremely 80's. Playing gives me a sense of nostalgia, because it is everything people thought VR would be like three decades ago. 

You will work up a sweat in the higher difficulties, and may need to 'air-out' your HMD every few minutes.

At $10, this is a great price-point for Holoball. The music is great, and the gameplay is surprisingly responsive for the speed of the game. It is a great game to demo for those new to VR. The only improvement I can think to make is updating the voice of the robot overlord narrator. Although the banter is funny, it is just a little hard to hear.

HOLOlujah! This game is BALLer!

Imagine if the original 1974 Pong, had a baby with a colorful, virtual 3-Dimensional environment. Then, that child grew up, and had a baby with the classic indoor sport of racquetball. That wonderful, miracle, of a baby, is named; HoloBall!

HoloBall is a competitive sport-like game in which takes place in what appears to be a neon version of a racquetball court. The goal is to win against a snarky, sarcastic, comedic AI, and attempting to get the highscore to get your name up on the leaderboard. Doing so, immenses a challenge and a great amount of fun! The different difficulty levels, really help to match your level of skill. The harder the difficulty, the larger the court and the smaller the ball. The racket has perfect physics! It feels all so very natural swinging at the ball attempting to get it passed the AI. Not only is this game a large amount of fun, its a great workout too if you really get into it! 

I highly recommend purchasing this game for anyone who even has a slight interest in; Racquetball, Tennis, or even the original Pong.

Warning: DON'T LET GO OF YOUR CONTROLLER! (Racket)

23147446.review:
I put off buying this game for a while because it's basically advertised as Pong in VR, and I've played far too much Pong in my day. I could have never imagined how much fun this game would be though.

Everything about it is very polished, and the end result is that it's like having a racquetball court in your living room, The colorful, holographic art style is perfect for a VR game, the difficulty at the higher levels is definitely enough to give you a challenge (and a workout), and the AI says some pretty funny things. As with almost all VR games out now, it could be longer or have a little more variety in the environments or game modes, but for what it costs, it's worth every penny.

It's simple but the design is very efficient and the game is tons of fun! If you have a vive this is one of the games you have to get and experience. It's very replayable (I play a couple of matches every day now) and it's a game where you actually have to be physically active, you feel good after playing it and it really makes you want to beat the ai.

It isn't as polished as it could be and after beating the expert mode (which will take you some while until you get there) there is only one mode left which is kind of endless. So the content could be bigger.

I hope the developers will add multiplayer matches and an ai mode in which you set in more detail how fast he should be or how hard he can play the ball back at you. Also I wish the matches would be longer, so it actually feels like a squash or tennis match.

Can highly recommend it but I hope there will be more content soon in form of a dlc or so.

22822783.review:
If Holopoint is the game that will make you hate the Vive's breakout box, Holoball is the game that will make you hate its wrist straps. I personally haven't had any experiences with anyone letting go of the controller yet, but I've seen plenty of evidence elsewhere, and it's a bit telling that Nintendo has suddenly sold out of every color of wrist strap except the basic white, so if you don't always keep a good grip or know someone who might not be too careful then you might want to get a beefier wrist strap before you play this one. 

As for the game itself, it's simple but fun, like most of the cheaper Vive games I've played. It's sort of like pong mixed with tennis, in which you play against an AI. If you've got a spectator they can also take over the AI and play with WASD, but in my experience they won't stand a chance and it's better to just leave it to the computer. There are four difficulties that you unlock as you complete the previous one, and it can be a pretty good workout on the later difficulties. It's not necessarily the sort of thing that's super impressive on a technological level, but for the price it offers a fair amount of entertainment unless you manage to break your wrist strap, in which case the only people being entertained may be the TV repair company.

22775424.review:
Disclaimer: I received free a key on Reddit from the developers

HoloBall is a great little mashup of racket-ball and pong, mixed with the post-apocalyptic robot humor that reminds me a bit of GladOS from Portal. Absolutely worth the price of admission!

Good:

Very fun to play, easy to pick up and hard to master (I can't make it beyond the Hard difficulty). I love this visual style, reminicent of the old Tron movie mixed with some polygon backgrounds from the old Virtual Boy era. Sense is scale is really nice, feels like you are in a big hall/hangar. One thing I absolutely loved was the haptic feedback of the racket. It has this long veil/ribbon streaming out of the back and as you move it, you feel it swoosh around. Really sold me on having that sci-fi racket in my hand instead of the Vive controller.

Bad:

A bit barebones with regards to gameplay modes and options, but the base game has enough to offer initially. Future updates should include more modes (many balls come toward you, specific areas of the court give more points/are blocked, etc) and possibly power-ups (more balls, racket size changes etc). Multiplayer would also be very cool but it would require big changes to the gameplay (can't go as high vertically). One final note of warning: make sure you have a lot of space or stand as far back as you can! I have about 2.8x2.3m and was so immersed and focused on winning and smashing the ball that I scratched the controller on the wall twice in a row the first time I played it. I had no problems being aware of the bounds and not hitting them with any of my other games, so be warned!

I have owned a VIVE for about a week now and spent rediculous amounts of time "in there" as I love it so much.
This low priced, simple game is amazing and along with SPT my favourite game.

Developers have done something I havent seen on any other game too, those not in the game can actually control the camera to see what is going on in the game, and can control the "ai" part in the game. This is an amazing idea that no one else seems to have thought of, that I have found anyway.

It's like VR tennis combined with Pong against GLaDOS - great, skill-based fun that makes you move around A LOT. It's almost exercise - and not the sitting-on-the-sofa, waving a Wii-mote around kind either - there's no avoiding the fact you *have* to put yourself in the right place to intercept the ball.

The physics seems good - I notice they've simulated some spin on the starting shot to stop you lining it up like a putt and sticking it through the edge of the CPU side - but otherwise things behave pretty much as you'd expect.

Overall I'd call it challenging but satisfying, and the savings in squash court bookings will pay for it in no time!

22638414.review:
** DISCLAIMER: I was given a key to beta test this by the developer **

I've had an opportunity to spend some good time in this. I also had 5 other people who came over for a "Vive" party try it out as well. Long story short, the game is spectacular fun and should be an instant-buy if you like pong, enjoy racket ball, or like the Tron 80s style theme. The production value feels high, the music doesn't get old, and the AI taunting is a hilarious nice touch (though I'd recommend increasing the volume of the AI a little as it's hard to hear over the music). For the price they are asking right now, this is a steal!

The gameplay itself is well done. The ball reacts as I would expect it to and I never felt like the ball did something that shouldn't happen if I really was in 3d cube in real life fighting for the freedom of the human race. There are currently 5 game difficulty modes and on the highest endurance mode, the difficulty can be punishing and can be quite easy to break into a sweat trying to catch the ball coming at you. I do wish there were more gameplay options at times, whether it be an option to have 'power-ups' or have obstacles in the way, as after awhile pong even in VR does get monotonous. The developers have an excellent concept and great execution on their hands, so iterating on it should be fairly simple and something I hope to see in future updates.

All this said, the AI seems to have trouble handling balls that are at the absolute corners of the zone and leaves them completely alone or goes in the opposite direction of them. This means the AI is susceptible to 'trick' shots, many of which go at minimal speed and still somehow make it through the paddle. I was able to replicate this a few times by 'smacking down' at the ball as it came at me and see it completely lose speed, dribble to a corner, and slowly get past the AI paddle which didn't know what to do with it. I will note, it's obvious the AI dipping out on corner shots is design decision as you get a 'sweetspot' dialogue with extra points when you hit it. I understand why they did it, but it still feels a little immersion breaking. This was infrequent enough that it didn't feel game-breaking, but it was immersion breaking enough that I recommend to the devs to look into it.

For the price they are asking, the positives far outweigh the negatives so far, and I am looking forward to pushing to top the leaderboards on release. Great job guys!

22635410.review:
Disclaimer: I was provided a beta key by the developers prior to release.

HoloBall is a mix between Pong and racquetball, stylized with Tron-like art animations. The gameplay is simple: score against an AI by hitting the ball with one of your paddles. The game's difficulty ramps up as it continues and each round introduces a modifier such as speeding up the AI or increasing hit power.

Leaderboards encourage replayability and I'd love to see online multiplayer in the future. One thing to note is that you'll be swinging your controllers pretty hard. Make sure you have adequate play space and are aware of your position in your room. I'd personally like to see an outline of the play space much like Space Pirate Trainer to increase positional awareness. (Update: The developer has since added this along with other suggestions sent pre-release. Excellent turn around!) My play space is about 3.3m x 2.8m and I didn't have any issues beyond being overly cautious.

HoloBall takes a classic game into the world of VR and executes on this idea well. This is well worth the cost of admission, especially once you consider the launch sale.

22634525.review:
I had a chance to play this pre-release. The game is a blast to play. Think "pong for VR." Three modes: one zen (basically you hit it with yourself), easy/medium/hard vs AI, and endurance, which allows you to keep playing until you lose.

Beating the three difficulties doesn't take long, but climbing the leaderboards provides for something to come back to. The game lends itself perfectly to multiplayer (not yet in), and I can't wait for that.

Very polished as well. Any issues I had with the game were minor (occasionally easy to lose the ball blended against the background, sweet spot on the AI's wall that gives you an automatic point if you hit it is a little too generous).

One of the games I most enjoy, and keep thinking about after I'm done playing. "Just one more game."

22634069.review:
I was lucky enough to get an early access copy of the game on reddit. So while I played a paid copy of the game, I won't let this influence this review.


As someone enjoying sports involving rackets like Tennis or Badminton, I feel like this game is absolutely fantastic fun! Let's start with the concept. You hit a ball with a racket, either with your left or right hand, and watch as it travels towards a huge wall covered by a floating AI opponent platform. Said CPU tries to return the ball and the goal of course is to get the ball past the player. It's basically pong meeting squash. There are three alternate modes: „Zen“ is classic squash, with the player having to repeatedly hit the ball of a wall. Then there are three different difficulties for matches against an AI, each consisting of five games, first to score five wins a game. Players are rewarded points for winning and performing bonus actions like an ace serve, but get points substracted for time spent. In this highscore-based mode it's all about time basically. To round the content of, „Endurance“ has you playing against a bot with only three lives to survive. Fundamentally, you have to score as many points as possible without letting the ball get past you more than two times. While each mode contains more or less the same key gameplay elements, they still all play diverse. Zen is best played rather slow, as you want the ball to travel as slow as possible to be able to return it as precise as possible over and over again. On the three difficulty enemy encounters, I tend to play more and more aggressively. While „Easy“ really is quite easy, „Medium“ already managed to give me a workout. „Hard“ definitely is a challenge and I tend to absolutely smash the ball whenever possible to get past the enemy. Spanning five rounds each, the AI gets better with the rounds played. It moves faster or returns the ball harder, giving you a great progressive increase of difficulty even within the different modes. „Endurance“ also comes with a change-up in mechanics. While the three other enemy modes have a „sweetspot“ zone on the edges of the wall that you'll definitely want to hit, leaving the enemy no chance to reach it, this zone doesn't exist in Endurance. All my play in the three difficulty modes usually focusses on aiming at the sweetspot-zones, making it feel different to Endurance. Here, you need to out-play the enemy, once again involving forceful smashes and quick directional changes. All of the playing modes ultimately have you hitting the ball, but while incorporating the same mechanics, they still manage to feel different due to varied circumstances.

The actual gameplay is absolutely mad fun! The Vive controller just works awesome as a racket. I'm playing in a 3,8m x 1,8m space and the use of room scaling is fantastic. It can be quite exhausting running from one end to the other, though it never seemed unfair in my time with it. When the ball came through, I always knew I was too slow. All in all it feels like a work out, but a very fun one. As hard as I kept hitting the balls, I felt sore muscles just few hours later the first time I played it. The game encourages me to use both arms, as each hand is equipped with a racket. While you theoretically still can play with one controller using forehand and backhand hits, you're way better off using both. I'm usually terrible at doing anything with my non-dominant arm and as the game encourages me to still use it, I think it actually helps me getting better with it. At the start I couldn't hit a ball with it, but it has already gotten better at the end of my first session and it keeps improving. Haptic feedback on the controllers makes the swinging all the more satisfying.

One of the most fun experiences I've had in VR with the Vive so far has been jump-smashing a ball to victory. It feels so satisfying to run and jump, smashing the ball with as much force as possible. It makes me feel really bad-ass, especially if it's still precisely aimed at a sweetspot zone. The game becomes a frantic, awesome work out on both the Hard difficulty and Endurance, as the enemy tends to return the ball harder and harder. My reflexes are greatly tested as the ball can come back in any direction in my 3,8m playspace width. Smash the ball and you face quite a workout with the enemy giving you a real challenge.


With all the talk about smashing a controller around, I didn't come close to hitting any furniture or walls in my time with the game so far. There's a room requirement for a reason, and I think as long as you have the required 1.5m x 2m or greater, you're good to go. The room scale use seems perfect and thanks to Chaperone, I'm sure there won't be a case of destroyed furniture or controller :p I ended up hitting myself with the controllers though which is a first for me with the Vive. The heavy hitting makes it difficult to slow the controllers down in time in some occasions and thus I hit myself regularly in my first hour. The more I played though, the less this happened. But a short, important advice: It seems crucial to wear the controller wrist straps. All the smashing in combination with slippery hands can make controllers fly through the room. I actually had a controller slip happen to me, while wearing the straps though – thankfully. So remember to use them or you'll regret it.

Visually, the game is looking great. The neon colors are vibrant, though the black largely black background keeps it light on the eyes. The controller rackets feature some cool visual effects, but I would suggest not to hold them directly in front of your eyes – they are very bright. The visuals give me a Tron-esque vibe and it feels great. The sense of space is fantastic! Depending on the game mode and difficulty, you play in a smaller or larger hall. Especially the large one really impresses with the threedimensional portrayal and with the ball traveling longer than in the small room, it's part of the reason why this game feels very immersive. I tend to forget that I'm wearing the Vive and that is always a good sign! The CPU is trash-talking to you during play which is fun, even though its lines become repetitive after some matches.

With the most important aspects out of the way, there are some miscellaneous things I want to talk about. The menus are fantastic, very intuitive. All the modes are right in front of you (though you have to unlock some by completing the previous ones first) and you choose a mode by putting the controller into the respective icon. On top of that, the game has super quick loading times which always is a great plus in my book. I'd appreciate another way to access the leaderboards. Currently, you can see it before starting a new match. As an arcade game pretty much revolving around highscores, I would appreciate a simpler way of having a quick look at the leaderboard. Also, I tend to press the Vive home button when things get heated so I'd wish for an option to disable all button presses while playing. Nitpicking though :) The game feels very polished and I've yet to face any kind of bug.Just a short disclaimer: All of my experience is based on the build that I played on the weekend before official release. I didn’t see any patch provided so I assume the final version is the exact same as I played. As polished as it is, there’s no real need for a patch anyway. 


Holoball is a very fun experience and I can see myself playing this every day for some small workout. Three modes with increasing difficulties play more diverse than I thought and chasing highscores quickly got me hooked. The price of 10 bucks is great and if you can imagine yourself having at least a tiny bit of fun equipped with two rackets, smashing every ball the AI is testing you with, I can fully recommend the game to you. If you don't mind a little workout, you're in for an insanely fun game that has you jump-smashing ball for ball like a badass!

22633997.review:
Upon entering the game the first impression I got was a tron vibe. The graphics are simplistic and colorful but have a sharp design style.

The opening lobby is an empty room that contains a number of pedestals with different difficultly levels on each one. initially, the only selectable difficulties are Zen (practice mode) and easy.

I started off with easy mode.

The ball is tee'd up for you to hit and the controls are simple. You swing at the ball and, depending on how hard and what angle you hit it at, it will direct your shot. You want to aim at the sweetspot (outside edges) or angle your shot to bounce off of one or multiple walls. The object, just like pong, is to outwit and outshoot your AI opponent looking to return your serve.

Also, it is good to note there is a leaderboard which I think is a staple and necessary in any arcade type game. It's just another carrot on a stick to keep users striving to do better and encourages players to continue coming back to the game. In the current iteration the leaderboard is only visible once you enter the room. My suggestion is having a way to bring up the leaderboard without having to leave the game and come back.

After some witty quips from my computer opponent I took my shot. WHAM, ACE +100 points. First impressions are great, the accuracy relies completely on the user ability to control the motion controls and the speed in which the shot is taken.

The AI opponent is comical with its retorts and it motivates me to hit my shots correctly.

There are 5 rounds and the player has to reach 5 points in any game, before the AI, to move onto the next round.

I did well and made my way through easy without too much difficulty and was very amazed at how much fun it is to play. I quickly restarted easy to get a better position on the leaderboard.

After getting my bearings I moved onto medium difficulty.

My first impression was that the room increased in size. Ok, that's a cool idea and mechanic.

Quickly, I realized my 7 ft tall ceilings were not going to suffice for any difficulty past easy.

I tried my best to not crush my ceilings, but unfortunately a number of shots went above my reach and it happened regardless.

I made my way through Medium with some lackluster results after restarting a couple times and having learned to let some shots just go by to save my drop-tile ceilings.

I moved onto hard and the room grew bigger. After the first return, I had to leave as a lot of the shots were above my head.

After trying out Zen difficulty I found an equal amount of fun to be had in this very different racquetball type style training simulator.

I did not notice any bugs in the initial testing I've done but will continue to check out the game and see if I find any in time.

So, after an hour of testing I think this game has a ton of potential. The controls are very intuitive and the gameplay is inviting and fun. The difficulty ramps up fairly but my main complaint is that you would probably need at least 9' ceilings in the games current iteration if you are a tall individual like me at 6'3".
